translated: Volume 2 of the Collected Works of Master of the Sea of Words
Written by Qi Song, a monk from Dongshan in Tengzhou, the Sea of Words
Chapter on Assisting the Teaching, Part 2
Preface to the Extensive Origins of Teaching.
In the past, I used the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds.
The five constants of Confucianism as the origins of teaching.
I urgently wanted to resolve the criticism of Buddhism by contemporary Confucians.
If the great foundation of teaching by our sage.
Although I have a general understanding, I have not had time to speak of it in detail.
I want to wait to write a separate book to elaborate on it.
The Origins of Teaching was transmitted for seven years.
Then Danqiu Changji sent a letter.
Encouraging me to complete it.
Although it was written, because the discussion was not yet complete, I burned it.
Just referring to his letter.
Almost getting to the mind of the sage.ğŸ”½At the beginning, I wrote the Origins of Teaching.
Taking the Bodhisattva Vehicle as the basis, I listed it first.
It takes the so-called method of relying on the root to give rise to the branches.
Taking the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom as the basis, I combined and separated the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds.
However, each person has their own style of expression.
Those who do not know this may criticize or be surprised by it.
At that time, some may have changed it for them.
Now the book first lists the human and heavenly vehicles.
It also follows the so-called gathering the branches and returning to the root chapter of the Huayan Sutra.
The five precepts and ten wholesome deeds are truly profound, and their names and numbers are no longer mentioned.
The reason I wrote these two books is
to clarify the great principles of the teachings established by the sages of the past.
To inform those Confucian scholars of the world who do not know about Buddhism.
Therefore, my words are meant to be literary, and my principles are meant to be concise.
It is not possible to branch out and speak in a rambling manner.
If I were to discuss in detail the teachings and meanings of the various sutras,
then there would be chapters and sentences.
Those who criticize me should understand the original teaching and expand on the original teaching.
The Expanded Original Teaching consists of twenty-five chapters.
In total, it has over 8,100 words.
This year is the year of the Fire Monkey. I wrote it in the Yong'an Mountain Retreat in Lingyin.
What is called the Way is the mind.
Teaching is called the manifestation of the Way.
Teaching is the manifestation of the sages.
The Way is the great foundation of sentient beings.
Sentient beings have long been deluded about their foundation.
The sages do not create, yet myriad things would remain obscure.
The sages thus illuminate the Way for myriad things.
The mind has no outside, and there is nothing that is not within it.
Therefore, there is nothing that is not included in the Way.
The sages do not favor the Way or abandon things.
The Way exists, and the sages accord with it.
Therefore, their teachings
pervade the profound, the luminous, and the mundane and supramundane.
There is nothing they do not pervade.
Pervade means to encompass.
They encompass and rectify it.
They wish to make everyone share the same virtue as the sages.
Nothing is greater than the Way in its vastness, spirituality, and illumination.
Nothing is greater than the mind in its numinous virtue and wondrous function.
Nothing is greater than the delusion of the foundation in following delusions and binding karma.
Nothing is greater than birth and death in drifting and wandering through the realms of existence.
There is nothing better than the sages in knowing the faults of sentient beings.
There is nothing better than establishing teachings in rectifying the basis of myriad things.
Righteousness is solid, clarity is solid, wonder is solid, and its Way is condensed.
Therefore, teachings are the great principles by which sages clarify the Way and save the world.
As for teachings,
they are the great function of sages responding to circumstances and to capacities beyond comprehension.
Therefore, for those with great capacities, they are taught suddenly;ğŸ”½for those with small capacities, they are taught gradually.ğŸ”½Gradual means provisional;
sudden means real.
The real is called the Great Vehicle;
the provisional is called the Lesser Vehicle.
The sages use the Great and Lesser Vehicles to encompass the various capacities,
and the profound and the manifest are all included.
Those who are ready for the sudden teaching hear the gradual teaching; those who are ready for the gradual teaching hear the sudden teaching.
This is also the wonder of the sages in accord with the heavens and humans, which humans and gods cannot fathom.ğŸ”½The sages show the provisional in order to lead to the real;
the sages reveal the real in order to rely on the provisional.
Therefore, provisional and real, biased and perfect, have never been mutually exclusive.
Provisional means manifest provisional and obscure provisional.
The sages' manifest provisional methods are shallow teachings and small paths.
They are the place of rest for those who have faith.
The sages' obscure provisional methods are different paths, other teachings, and doing the same things as good and evil.
They are the distant conditions for attaining the Way for those who have no faith.
The manifest provisional can be seen.
But the obscure provisional is unfathomable.
Real means ultimate reality.
In ultimate reality, things and I are one.
Since things and I are one, the sages perfect them with all living beings.
Speaking of the sages' provisional means,
it extends throughout the world's goodness.
It pervades the paths of a hundred schools.
What great provisional means for saving the world and benefiting beings!
Speaking of the sages' reality,
Then, does it pervade the Dharma realm and is it the great Way of exhausting the principles and fulfilling the nature of all things under Heaven?
The sage is the sage of sages.
Using what is not birth and death, he shows birth and death, being the same as others.
Yet no one can see the reason for it.
Is he not the sage of ancient spiritual wisdom, vast and perfect?
Therefore, his teachings have the Way of the Spirit.
They have the Way of Humanity.
They have constant virtue.
They have extraordinary virtue.
They cannot be sought in a single way.
If lost, it lies in the comparison of traces.
In governing people and governing Heaven, nothing is better than the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds.
Cultivating the small sages and small sagehood.
Nothing is greater than the four truths and twelve links of dependent arising.
Cultivating the great sagehood and progressing to the great sagehood.
Nothing is greater than the six perfections and myriad practices.
As for the five precepts and ten wholesome deeds,
They are the means by which one attains Heaven.
The reason why they rely on people is
in terms of their accomplishments, there are superior and inferior.
In terms of their principles, the Way of the great person is one.
As for the Four Noble Truths and the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination,
if separated, they are in the small sage.
If combined, they are in the small of the small sage.
In terms of their accomplishments, there are flourishing and killing.
In terms of what they ride, the small sage and the small of the small sage share the same path.
As for the Six Perfections,
they are the head of myriad practices and the breadth of myriad practices.
The great sage is with the great of the great sage.
Although what they ride is slightly divided,
when it comes to surpassing the ultimate with myriad practices,
then it is the same as the great of the great sage.
As for myriad practices, they are called myriad wholesome deeds.ğŸ”½The sage's wholesome deeds
are essentially spiritual.
Adapting to changes and riding the transformation, there is nowhere they are not.
Therefore, the sage anticipates the affairs of Heaven and humans,
but Heaven and humans cannot fathom them.
The spirit is marvelous.
The affairs are coarse.
The coarse is known only by the people.
The marvelous is known only by the sages.
The world competes with each other in terms of self and others.
Using the affairs of Confucianism and Buddhism to judge right and wrong.
And those who know the affairs of Confucianism and Buddhism in the world.
How can they know the clay and tiles of Confucianism and Buddhism?
The sentient beings pervade the heavens and earth, theå¹½ and the æ˜, the barbarians and beasts.
Not by the spiritual way pervading.
But ancient and modern times have almost abandoned things.
The sages value the same spirit and fear abandoning things.
Therefore, the sages use the spiritual way to create.
The mind must be utmost, and the utmost must change. Change is consciousness.
The utmost is suchness.
Suchness is the marvelous of myriad things.
Consciousness is the myriad things' differences and distinctions.
Change is the subtlety of movement.
The utmost is the root of marvel.
There is nothing in the world that is not rooted.
There is nothing in the world that does not move.
Therefore, all things emerge from change and enter into change.
All things arise from the ultimate and return to the ultimate.
The changes of all things are seen in emotions.
The ultimate of the world lies in human nature.
With emotions, one can discern the changes of all things.
With human nature, one can observe the great wonder of the world.
Indeed, emotions and human nature can be used to speak of the teaching and way of the sages.
The mind is called the common spirit of all things.
The way is what the sages tread upon.
There are great ways.
There are small ways.
The mind has goodness.
It has evil.
Goodness and evil have degrees of thickness.
Greatness and smallness have levels of profundity.
Therefore, there are great sages, secondary sages, and lesser sages.
There are celestials, humans, asuras, ghosts and spirits.
There are birds and beasts, and the way of earth.
All living beings come from the same mind.
The sages are those who have departed from the single way.
The principles of the greatness and smallness of the sages cannot but be carefully examined.
The reasons for the goodness and evil of the multitude of beings cannot but be carefully considered.
The mind and the Way, how can they be different?
Using the sages and the multitude of beings, I will roughly distinguish them.
It is called the Way.
It is called the mind.
The mind, how great! How ultimate!
It is more profound than ghosts and spirits, more illuminating than the sun and moon.
Vast and great, it encompasses heaven and earth.
Subtle and fine, it penetrates the neighboring void.
It is profound yet not profound.
Therefore, it is the ultimate profundity.
It is illuminating yet not illuminating.
Therefore, it is the ultimate illumination.
It is great yet not great.
Therefore, it is the ultimate greatness.
It is subtle yet not subtle.
Therefore, it is the ultimate subtlety.
The essence of the sun and moon, the spirits of ghosts and spirits.
And it is wondrous in the three powers of heaven and earth.ğŸ”½It is as if it exists, as if it does not exist.
It is neither existent nor nonexistent.
It is not non-existent.
It is not non-existent.
Can this be described in words?
It cannot be explained by the profound understanding of absolute negation.
To attain it is in the twinkling of an eye.
To miss it is by a hair's breadth.
This can be known by those who have attained it.
It cannot be discussed with learners.
The sages found it difficult to clarify and difficult to attain.
They established various teachings.
Explaining it, discussing its principles, illustrating it, and rectifying it.
Although there are many aspects,
they all wish to prevent people from being deluded.
Yet learners are still confused.
Now, those who mix up the world and call it the mindğŸ”½speak of it but do not elaborate.
They know it but do not examine it carefully.
If they recognize consciousness and think they have attained the same understanding of the Way as the sages,
isn't it far-fetched?ğŸ”½Emotions arise from nature.
Nature is hidden in emotions.
When nature is hidden, the ultimate truth ceases.
Therefore, the sages use nature as their teaching to teach people.
The movements of the world arise from emotions.
The confusions of myriad things are rectified by nature.
The goodness and evil of human nature are not something that can be thoroughly examined in the world.
Knowing goodness and evil but not knowing the beginning and end of goodness and evil,
is that ultimate knowledge?
Knowing the end but not knowing the beginning,
is that ultimate knowledge?
Only the sage's ultimate knowledge,
knows the beginning, knows the end, knows the subtle, and knows extinction.
Seeing it penetrate through the obscurity of life and death, and form images and forms in the universe, it arises from human emotions.
The universe is vast, yet it is contained within human nature.
Therefore, nothing is more flourishing than human emotions and nature.
Emotions are the beginning of existence.
With existence, there is love.
With love, there are desires.
With desires, there are men and women, the myriad things, and life and death.
The feelings of life and death lead to the transformation of good and evil.
Beginning and end revolve around life and death, never ceasing.
Nature is the ultimate of non-existence.
At the ultimate of non-existence, it has never been non-existent.
Coming out of birth and entering into death, yet not death, not birth.
The Way of the sages is thus tranquil yet illuminating.
It only responds to what is appropriate.
As for emotions, they are false and discriminating.
When obtained, they become love and favoritism.
They become close to the close and distant from the distant, sometimes good, sometimes bad.
When lost, they become deceit and cunning.
They become violent and disrespectful.
They become greedy and indulge in desires.
They lose the mind and destroy the nature.
As for nature, it is true, as it is, ultimate, without evil, pure, and still.
Approaching it, one becomes virtuous and upright.
Far from it, one becomes a sage, a spiritual being, a great sage.
The sage takes nature as his teaching, teaching people without using emotions.
This is its essence.
The presence of emotions and nature in things
Is always so, clearly so.
Investigating it, it cannot be found.
Cutting through it, it is not severed.
Heaven and earth may have an end, but the spiritual nature is inexhaustible.
The five destinies may change, but the burden of emotions is not released.
Therefore, the nature and emotions of the world cannot but be distinguished.
As for teaching people with emotions,
they are in the realm of birth and death.
As for teaching people with nature,
they transcend birth and death.
Emotional teaching is near,
while natural teaching is far.ğŸ”½To be born beyond birth and death and to be ignorant of it,
is to be oblivious to the principle of Heaven and to cut off the source of life.
Small knowledge is not as good as great knowledge.
Is it not also so that a small chicken is confined within a jar?
When the mind moves, it is called karma.
The convergence of karma is called response.
Response is called the commonality of the inner and outer.
What mind in the world does not move?
What karma of myriad things does not respond?
The principle of karma is subtle.
The force of response is far-reaching.
Therefore, the people do not see it and are not afraid.
The teaching of the sages is to be cautious in karma.
They want the people to be surely vigilant.
I wish for the mind to be cautious in movement.ğŸ”½The inner response is called summoning.
The outer response is called resonance.
Summoning refers to the cause.
Resonance refers to the effect.
The images of cause and effect are all preordained.
The movement of the mind has opposition and accord.
Therefore, the emotions of good and evil arise.
Once the emotions of good and evil have been aroused,
The responses of misfortune and blessings arrive.
The emotions have shallow and deep levels.ğŸ”½The retribution has light and heavy degrees.
The light can be changed.
The heavy cannot be averted.
Good and evil have a sequence.
Misfortune and blessings have a pace.
Even if it is ten or ten thousand generations, those who resonate do not escape.
How can it be only one generation?
If good and evil are not verified in one generation and are doubted,
This is also being confused about cause and effect.
Retribution and giving are not based on the correctness of cause and effect.
Then how can the world encourage goodness in people?
The tree is not seen to grow and flourish day by day.
Li does not see it being exhausted, but the sun is gone.
The existence of karma in humans is like this.
Can it not be taken seriously?
Things have natures and things have destinies.
Things like to be born and dislike death.
All those with blood and breath are like this.
The reason why sages want to give life and do not want to kill is
Life and death have causes and effects.
Goodness and evil have corresponding responses.
If the cause is good, the effect is good.
If the cause is evil, the effect is evil.
The mind that likes life is good.
The mind that likes killing is evil.
Can the responses of goodness and evil not be taken seriously?
People eat things and things provide for people.
In the past, they owed each other and secretly repaid each other.
This is the way karma works.
People and things do not realize it.
They say that things naturally arise from heaven to nourish people.
How could heaven be so biased?
Harming life and death to nurture life and death.
The way of heaven is extremely benevolent, how could it be so?
The principle of mutual repayment is profound and difficult to speak of.
The force of slaughter accumulates and is difficult to stop.
Therefore, the ancient laws did not allow the violent killing of animals, nor the encirclement or trapping of groups.
The Duke of Zhou used fishing hooks but not nets, and did not shoot birds at night.
This is the gradual cessation of killing.
Buddhism teaches people to give life and not kill.
Can it not be thought about? It is indeed so.
Great faith is near.
Small faith is far.
Near is reversed to far, far is reversed to near.
This is due to the obstruction of emotions.
Nothing is closer to the mind in the world.
Nothing is farther from things in the world.
If a person does not believe in their mind but believes in things,
isn't it also reversing near to far and far to near?
Isn't it also confused, deluded, inverted, and mistaken?
The mind is the source of intelligence, clarity, and wisdom.
If one does not obtain the source, how can what is emitted not be deluded?
The reason why the sages want people to believe in their own minds is
to believe in their minds and rectify them.

With sincere clarity, one can move Heaven and Earth and shake the spirits.

Those who are almost there.

They are water.
They are gold.

Teaching people but not teaching other kinds?
Do things have something they leave behind?
The obscure and distant,

What humans cannot reach,
The sages are able to reach it.

The sages are able to commiserate with it.

The sages cannot rectify it,

Therefore, the teachings of the sages pervade far and near, the profound and the bright, without exception, without attachment.
In the vastness of the world,
Who can compare to the teachings of our sages?
The highest of Heaven,
The farthest of Earth,
The most profound of ghosts and spirits,
Cultivate the methods of our sages and Heaven and Earth will respond to it.
Uphold the words of our sages and ghosts and spirits will comply with it.
Heaven and Earth have the same mind as the sages,
Ghosts and spirits have the same numen as the sages.
This is so because they resonate with each other.ğŸ”½If feelings are different, people will be estranged.
If types are different, things will be opposed.
If it is not the Way, even infants will not follow it.
Now, it moves Heaven and Earth and shakes the spirits.
It is obtained by the common people and barbarians.
It changes from ancient times to the present, yet its mind is not apart.
Then, the Way of our sages can be seen to be greatly inclusive and supremely profound.
What is meant by Buddha?
It is the rectification of the One.

Buddha and person are only one.

Grasping the name and being confused about the reality,

The Way, being in the Buddha, is called the effect.
The cause refers to what has not yet been attained.
The effect refers to what has been attained.
When attained, it is rectified.
When rectified, there is nowhere it does not naturally obtain itself.

I am also so.

their harm is the same.

Shi Hu,
